X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=LR8ldchPE7uDToOBR0t-5Ic19xmVynEwe9NZIQY3wFjvhKco

                   Hi,

"Aidan Morgan" <aidos@...> wrote :

| I am trying to replicate the "hard" learning problem from the
| behavioural diversity papers that have recently been discussed on
| the mailing list. I have a few ideas I would like to try out, but I
| would like to be able to compare them to the original research to
| see if I can get any improvement.
 
| I have two questions to ask of those of you who have tried
|  recreating this:
 
I have recreated it in a slightly different setup (the change were
made to simplify the implementation in my framework and the potential
implementation on a real robot). In my experience, the results were
easy to reproduce and does not depends much on the details.

For details about my implementation, you can check the paper that I
will present at the IROS workshop ("Exploring new horizons of
Evolutionary Design of Robots", see the next message):
http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/papers/novelty_based_multiobjectivization.pdf

| 1. How big is the area? I have got all of the internal "walls" in
| place in scale to the total size of the map, however I would like to
| get a rough idea of the width/height of the "map". I understand that
| this should all be relative, but without some sort of "scale factor"
| for my map from the original I don't know what is a reasonable
| amount of space for the agent to move etc. Currently my world is 120
| x 115 units big, and the agent can move anywhere up to 2.5 units per
| time period.
 
My hard map is 500x500 px, that are transformed into a 600x600 units
maze. The radius of my robot is 20 units. Each wheel can make up 2
units per time step and I used 1500 time-steps for the whole
simulation.


| 2. I also am interested in how the outputs of the neural network are
| interpreted. I know from the papers that there are two output
| neurons, one for forward/backward and one for left/right. Currently
| I am interpreting these as output < 0.5 = turn left, output > 0.5 =
| turn right and the same for forward/backward. This is leading to a
| pretty constant behaviour of moving in circles around the map,
| always turning left - so I am wondering how other people have
| interpreted the output result to get a more intelligent movement
| pattern.

I used a different robot than in the original paper. The main reason
was to have outputs similar to the ones you could use on a small
mobile robot. I have two outputs: 
- speed of the right wheel
- speed of the left wheel

I can send you my source code in you think it can be useful. 

Best regards,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
